awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Friendsourcing to Detect Network Manipulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally, security on the Internet has been concerned with threats posed by edge nodes (hosts) to other hosts and to the middle nodes of the network (routers). However, in recent years,a rising number of instances in which hosts seek to defend themselves against the middle of the network can be seen. Examples include censorship and network neutrality violations, which fall into a general category of ?network manipulation?.

This project is exploring how to detect network manipulation through ?friendsourcing?, a strategy in which individuals use their social networks to get measurements from their friends. The project is developing a framework to facilitate this basic mechanism of analysis by addressing coverage, instrumentation, and co-operation. To obtain coverage, it must be possible to carry out recruitment that finds a collection of hosts in the right network locations. To deploy instrumentation, a software system capable of making the necessary measurements must be set up in such locations. To gain co-operation, it is necessary to rely on friending to get the help needed to realize the coverage and use the instrumentation.

Initial studies use limited coverage based on close friending and manual instrumentation. Later studies use broader coverage with theoretical underpinnings, more modular instrumentation, weaker friending ties, and more participants. Studies use a blend of theory (of coverage), software architecture (for instrumentation) and social network binding (to assess levels of cooperation). These studies provide better foundations for understanding the capacity of social networks and friendsourcing to measure Internet behavior and address network manipulation.

por.por_cntn:
The Friendsourcing project began with work on using social networks to serve as a means to gain vantage points that would help determine whether network manipulation (such as censorship) was taking place. This initial part of the project culminated in a study that used social networking in India to discover censureship being used by ISPs there to restrict speech they deemed to be inflammatory. The use of social media to gain multiple vantage points to understand the nature and scope of, say, the actions of governments has now become a common technique of activists. The project was able to contribute some technology to those aims and address the issue theoretically. After the initial work on this goal, the project turned to a range of topics, mostly involving the design, implementation, and testing of  tools related to the security and privacy of smartphones. Contributions in this area included (1) a tool called Pluto that can mine collections of smartphone apps and find out which ones collect the most information of interest to advertisers, (2) a language and system called Draco that enables developers working with embedded browsers on smartphones to precisely specify access rights to address problems that arise from the complexity of sharing interfaces to web content, (3) a set of techniques showing how a commodity smartphone on a factory floor could be used to detect key features of parts being made with 3D printers and CNC mills by using acoustic and electromagnetic information collected by the smartphone, (4) a collection of algorithms that use information on smartphones to learn about smartphone user interests in order to improve the efficiency of auto-completion of user searches in a browser, (5) an architecture called HanGuard to enable a smartphone to effectively configure a home router using software defined networking  to support security restrictions for Internet of Things (IoT) devices, (6) a tool called ProvThings that collects causal dependencies between events in an IoT environment so they can be represented in a provenance graph that can be used for debugging, detection of security issues, and other applications, and (7) a tool called MineGuard that uses hardware measures to detect the illegitimate use of cryptocurrency mining on computers such as those of cloud providers and enterprise systems. These and other contributions have aided our understanding of network manipulation, privacy on smartphones, IoT security, side channels created by smartphones, and abuses of computing systems by cryptocurrency mining.


Last Modified: 11/05/2017
Modified by: Carl Gunter
